div.head: Open Session, February 17, 1994, 9:10 - 10:25 A.M.
div.p: Chairman Kimball opened the meeting at 9:10 a.m. He introduced and welcomed Melvyn Leffler who replaced Bradford Perkins. Leffler is a professor of American diplomatic history at the University of Virginia and is the new president of SHAFR. Kimball explained the 3-year rotation of new Committee members.

He asked if the members wanted any changes in the agenda. Herring said he wanted to delay his subcommittee report; Kimball asked Chaddic to be available to hear Herring’s report. Picker said that her report would be incomplete but no delay was necessary. Van Camp confirmed her scheduled time.

Kimball asked for approval of the minutes. Slany announced that he has received amendments that are not in the text the Committee has. The Committee decided to postpone agreement until the members could review the changes.

head.hi: Remarks by Deputy Assistant Secretary Bennett Freeman

div.p: DAS Bennett Freeman stated that the Foreign Relations series has made great progress in the last 2-3 months and the Committee has engaged the attention of both the A and DS Bureaus. A “constructive dialogue” has begun on both the 30-year issue and PRD 29. The December 15 meeting was a “real breakthrough” where both sides expressed their concerns and criticisms. The Committee’s advocacy has made a difference and its views are being taken seriously.
Kimball thanked Freeman and asked Slany for his report.

head.hi: Report by the Historian, William Z. Slany

div.p: Slany reported that the 1991-1992 plan is generally being adhered to; more than 18 print volumes and microfiche supplements will be released. The backlog of volumes compiled in the 1980s is being eliminated but the series will probably not meet the the 1996 deadline. Not even all the Eisenhower volumes are cleared.

Declassification is a process that we control “least effectively.” He then made reference to a report prepared by David Herschler and staff addressing issues of declassification and its problems, which had been given to Committee members earlier. The bottleneck, which is not within the State Department but at other agencies, has gotten worse since last November; only one volume has been cleared in the last five months. 15-18 volumes are being delayed. Assistant Secretary Donilon has addressed a letter to CIA Executive Secretary Hazlewood who has responded. But Slany made it clear that the CIA has failed to address Foreign Relations declassification problems. In fact, no one from CIA will be at the meeting today.

Slany noted that Pereira differs with HO on the number of volumes cleared and uncleared. We have communicated our problems to CIA and Pereira has said that he would have 40 people by late spring. But the delay continues and each delay drives further delays. The process is so complicated that even if CIA clears 15-18 volumes, HO couldn’t publish the necessary number of volumes this fiscal year because of further necessary clearances at NSC (which has a small clearance staff). He could not tell the Committee with “candor” that the 1994 schedule can be met.

Slany said the PA Bureau leadership has supported the Office. Maybe HO can make up the 1994 shortfall in 1995 in order to meet the schedule. He noted that a paper in the briefing package delineated these problems.

Kimball asked if the CIA had responded to the letter. Slany said that they had replied and acknowledged the predicament. The Committee read the letter, and Nelson noted it was a “non-answer.” Slany said that in a conversation he had with Pereira, Pereira said the CIA was assigning more resources to Foreign Relations and in the future more Foreign Relations volumes would be cleared.

Herring asked if now was the time for the Committee to take action. Kimball said yes. Glad noted that the letter made no mention of new declassification standards. Slany said no, they were using the old standards. She asked if they were willing to release the word “covert.” Slany replied they the agency had not altered their position on CIA involvement.
Nelson said that having so many levels of clearance and requiring referral of documents to many agencies was an involved way to declassify documents.

Rosenberg asked if it were possible to get Pereira to appear before the Committee. Kimball asked for Committee approval for him to call David Griese to have someone come from the CIA to discuss this problem and explain CIA’s delay. If no one will come, the Committee should draw up a formal response. All agreed and discussion of this was postponed.

Chaddic asked if he could make a brief report. HDR has begun to seek Bureau clearance at the end of State’s 120-day period rather than at the end of the NSC clearance period. But he needs to know when and what volumes will be coming to his office so he can schedule a reviewer. Kimball said the Committee agreed at its last meeting that effective, realistic schedules are essential for both HDR and HO.

After reviewing Herschler’s summary report on declassification (Section H) Kimball noted an interesting problem. Herschler was candid about problems in and out of HO. He asked if the Committee could hear more about the problem. Herschler explained the process of re-review at HO request. In the case of the 1958-1960 volume on national security policy, however, HDR initiated a complete re-review of the manuscript, resulting in additional releases and referrals to other agencies. He wants HDR to consult with HO before such referrals.

Pryor said that this re-review occurred for that volume and for the 1965 Vietnam volume. When the reviewer died and HDR reviewed his files, it noticed that a lot of material was releasable, especially concerning U.S.-Soviet relations (the initial review had begun in the mid-1980s). HDR has a responsibility to release Department of State material and to make the releases consistent. This will not be a routine procedure, but HDR has this responsibility, especially if there is a sudden change in the parameters of U.S. foreign policy that allows material to be released.
Kimball pointed out that the Committee has a dilemma: quality versus sticking to the schedule, in both of which the Committee is interested. “We never want quality to disappear.”

Van Camp said that Herschler was asking for consultation so HO could weigh the factors and make a decision. Kimball and Rosenberg stated that the re-review would not likely happen again. Chaddic pointed out that it shouldn’t happen under the 120-day time limit.
Nelson noted that HDR is willing to change its procedures but CIA is not.
Picker asked Pryor how many documents had been released from the re-review. Pryor said about 50-60 documents in each volume.

Rosenberg asked for an explanation of the CIA “paperwork” delays. Herschler explained that delay occurred between the office that does the review and the office that logs out documents and writes the response to HO.

Rosenberg next asked about “late referrals.” Herschler explained that this involved documents newly compiled or documents recently identified. LaFantasie added that these documents were the result of new research. Herring asked if this new research was occurring across the board for all volumes. LaFantasie told him that the new research was being done selectively at the CIA and at the Johnson Library.

Rosenberg said it was too bad about the slippage in the schedule but she applauded the new research and the new documents. LaFantasie pointed out that HO needs to maintain the schedule because the law is definitive.

Glad asked if the supplemental documents would be released later. Kimball said that HO is investigating if there are a sufficient number of documents available for Iran and Guatemala supplements. Slany said that HO is investigating the feasibility. Slany and Kimball both expressed concern that the agencies would delay declassification because the documents could be published at a later date in a supplement.
Rosenberg asked about the covert activities supplemental volume. Kimball asked if we should ask CIA to give specific goals and schedules.

Taylor asked, regarding the review and release of additional information, if NARA would have the new material. Pryor and Chaddic said that NARA would but it would only be released after a request for re-review.
Kimball said that this issue, re-review of 1950s material after 30 years and the FOIA overload, should be on the agenda for the Committee’s next meeting.

In completing his report, Slany touched on the process the Historical Office was going through to recruit four professionals and a few support staff. The Office has been given permission to hire from outside the State Department but those people will have to go through the 6-month clearance process. The Department has given the Bureau money to publish these volumes; the failure to publish is not for lack of money.
Kimball noted that the questions raised at the last meeting are on the agenda.

Rosenberg commented that the Dominican crisis should not have a whole volume; we should not let military activity dictate Foreign Relations coverage. Keefer explained that the volume will cover the Dominican crisis, Cuba, and the Caribbean; another volume will cover all other Latin American subjects. The Office was committed to only two volumes on Latin America but they will both be more than 800 pages.
Kimball wanted to add this issue to the agenda for the next meeting: comprehensiveness in fewer pages (for the Johnson volumes). Kimball asked for the Perkins chart, which was distributed.

Next Nelson gave the report of the Rosenberg/Nelson/Taylor subcommittee. They went to Suitland to review the State declassification process. The subcommittee met with Marvin Russell (NARA) and William Hamilton (HDR). She reported that 221 boxes had been completed by January, but there was no way that the 30-year deadline of 1996 can be met.

State was working hard on the 1961-1963 Central files, which would be ready by 1996, and NARA was working on the Lot and Post files. The process for the 1964-1966 records was more problematic. HDR is just beginning to draw up guidelines; State could get through the Central files, but NARA could not complete the Lot and Post files.

The subcommittee was alarmed at the 1964-1966 period. HDR was doing the Central files; NARA was doing the Lot and Post files in a single review. The sheer volume of files was unbelievable. Langbart pointed out that the 1964-1966 Lot and Post files were still in the custody of State, but Rosenberg affirmed that the division of labor between State and NARA will remain.

Nelson said the subcommittee had a critical meeting with the declassifiers and asked how the Committee could sample the process and why the process was going faster. The subcommittee learned that the process was faster because declassifiers now had a one-stage process and there were more people. It was also clear that they had a different mindset to go quickly through non-sensitive material.

Regarding sampling, the subcommittee learned that each box has a folder with withdrawal slips. These withdrawal slips could give the Committee a way to sample the declassification process. One box had 150 withdrawals, all of which were documents with CIA equity.

Nelson also reported that this is a subjective process, and each document must be read for code words and sensitive words. She commented on the benefit of discussions among the State reviewers to agree on interpretation of texts. Kimball said the Committee must have the same interchange of ideas with NARA.

Rosenberg said that the reviewers estimate that up to 80 percent of tabbed (withdrawn) material was CIA equity. The CIA response to a written message for a CIA reviewer
was non-committal. The Committee should urge CIA to provide a reviewer to speed the process. Even if a CIA reviewer is present, however, unless the CIA changes its guidelines, he/she might not be the panacea we all think.
Smith commented that if the 1964-1966 Lot files were transferred to NARA before the compilers could do their research, the compilation of volumes would be slowed.
Rosenberg asked if anyone were taking responsibility for the 1964-1966 Lot and Post files. Kurtz said that NARA is dealing with the 1961-1963 records first.
Rosenberg said that the subcommittee had also learned that there is no money in the State budget to pay the annuitants in HDR; this would stop the process by March
1. HDR felt very threatened. Nelson asked if the Committee could help.
The meeting recessed for a break at 10:25 a.m.

div.head: Open Session, February 17, 1994, 10:50 - 12 Noon
div.p: At 10:50 a.m. the meeting resumed, and Kimball reminded speakers to speak up, and asked them to make it clear if the discussion is classified. He noted that the fact that a session was closed did not necessarily mean that it was classified.

head.hi: Status Report on the Draft Executive Order

div.p: Kimball then introduced John Hancock from the Diplomatic Security (DS) Bureau, who was there to discuss the draft executive orders on classification/ declassification. He reminded the Advisory Committee that Assistant Secretaries Quainton and Kennedy were also going to discuss these issues during the working luncheon.

Hancock began by saying that he was representing DS and noted that he had a longstanding involvement with declassification and the rules governing declassification. He reminded the Committee that PRD 29 had directed that the current executive order be revised and made relevant to the post-cold-war world.

In order to come up with a draft executive order, Steve Garfinkel, ISOO, had convened a task force with representatives from 20-odd agencies, on which he (Hancock) and Michael Kurtz from the National Archives (NARA) had both served.

Seven different task force committees had studied various classification/declassification issues such as levels of classification, how long material should remain classified, safeguards, and special access. The first draft executive order had come out in August 1993. Following extensive comments, it had been revised. The second draft order had come out on November 10, but Garfinkel had made it clear that this did not reflect a consensus. Since November, the draft order has been with the NSC staff.

It was pointed out by Hancock that the Department of State had worked very closely with the Advisory Committee
during this process, and noted that the Committee had said that they might use FRUS as a model because the systematic review procedures had been very successful. There had been a meeting with four Advisory Committee members in December 1993 which had resulted in a memorandum from Kimball in January 1994 expressing some of the Committee’s concerns with the draft order. These concerns had been raised with the NSC staff and with Under Secretary Moose.

In the meantime, the NSC staff was waiting for an evaluation of the draft by the Joint Security Commission, which was looking at all aspects of information security. The JSC report was supposed to have been issued on February 1 and was now scheduled for February 28. The Department of State would look very closely at this report.
Discussing the possibility of automatic declassification, at 6, 10, and 15 years, Hancock declared that without up-front exception the Department would have to review the documents.

Several Advisory Committee members pointed out that this meant that declassification would not be automatic. Hancock said that--in practice--documents would have to be reviewed to see if they contained information that should remain classified. Anna Nelson commented that this meant systematic review.

Page Miller noted that there was a language problem here. There was no “drop-dead date” in the draft order if the documents had to be reviewed. Emily Rosenberg asked what dates were being considered for automatic declassification. Hancock said that he was not sure but perhaps 10 and 25 years, and pointed out that this would constitute a serious problem for the Department depending on what up-front exceptions would be authorized.

George Herring asked what was likely to happen after February 28. Hancock replied that the NSC staff might put its report out for executive branch comments. Betty Glad asked whether the Advisory Committee would be able to comment on the final draft. Hancock replied that it would. Rosenberg noted that they would continue to discuss this during the working luncheon.

Melvyn Leffler asked which specific FRUS procedures would be desirable. Hancock replied that the Department with its current resources had been very successful with the current FRUS timeframe; 97% of the material reviewed had been declassified. Earlier reviews at 6, 10, and 15 years would be more expensive and far fewer documents would be released at the earlier dates.
Rosenberg pointed out that the lack of deadlines in the draft executive order were a problem for the Advisory Committee and suggested that the FRUS legislation might be a better model.

Kimball said that in response to a note from Bennett Freeman suggesting that FRUS be used as a model, he had sent a reply agreeing that there were certain aspects of the FRUS legislation that could be used as a model (such as the oversight committee), but pointing out that the Advisory Committee was not sure that the Department of State system was working as it should be and noting that it had unequivocally endorsed systematic review at 20 years and automatic declassification at 30 years.

Arnold Taylor asked whether the draft order discussed reclassification. Kimball noted that there were two kinds of reclassification--inadvertent disclosure and documents
that had been officially declassified. Concerning the first, the Advisory Committee was not sure, but it was absolutely opposed to reclassification in the second. He personally thought that it was stupid to reclassify even in the first instance, and noted that the Advisory Committee had suggested different language for the draft order.

Hancock commented that he did not remember the exact language, but he remembered that the Advisory Committee was not happy with it. After hearing that several Committee members did not have a copy of the November 10 draft, Hancock offered to provide them with copies.

Michael Kurtz of NARA informed the Advisory Committee that NARA had been working closely with the Department of State and said that he was there to report on what had been accomplished. 1.3 million pages from 1961-1963 had been opened for research, and NARA had also opened 1.3 million pages from the pre-1960 lot files. Kurtz said that NARA expected to complete its own work on review of the material through 1963 by April 1, but noted that there were serious concerns and serious budget problems.

NARA had been receiving Department of State financial support for declassification, but it was not clear whether this would continue. If it did not, it was questionable whether NARA would be able to follow-up on its previous Department of State work. He had met with Frank Machak to discuss what could be done. Kurtz noted that NARA was planning to integrate the 1964-1966 lot files into its move to Archives II in September 1994.

Rosenberg commented that when they talked about “finishing the job by 1996,” “job” seemed to mean 1961-1963 and not 1964-1966 and Kurtz replied yes. Kimball said that there seemed to be two solutions--more money and fewer declassification restrictions.

Taylor asked how long it would be before the files would be available. Kurtz responded that NARA would try to make them available as soon as possible. Kimball asked how the Advisory Committee could find out which lot files were not yet open. Kurtz said that NARA would provide a list.

Herring asked how NARA decided which lot files to process. Jean Schauble replied that some of this was researcher-driven. Nelson noted there was already a list of priorities for lot files drawn up by some SHAFR members. Miller pointed out that all of the files on that list were now open. Schauble said that NARA would provide the Committee with the newest list of what lot files had been opened.

Rosenberg wanted to know whether the declassification process had now become a single-staff reviewing process, and Schauble replied that it had. Rosenberg asked whether this meant that HDR no longer came by to re-review documents. Schauble said that this had not been done for years except for special issues or cases.

Kurtz said that he wanted to develop a companion draft executive order concerning NARA holdings appropriate for bulk declassification with a list of these divided into pre-1945 files (with 22 million pages still classified) and post-1945 files. Kurtz and Joe Chaddic agreed there would be cooperation and consultation between NARA and the Department of State. Kimball stated that the Advisory Committee clearly endorsed this.
Nelson commented that it was remarkable that so many pages had been processed, but reminded the Advisory Committee of its (1991?) report stating that NARA would have to do 10 million pages a year.

Chaddic said that there seemed to be some confusion concerning the 1964-1966 record block. He felt that the Department was on track and he did not intend to have a division of labor with NARA. His staff would do the entire process and give NARA a shelf-ready product. He noted that HDR did not have space. His personal office had been turned into a systematic review space and Ken Rossman’s office had become a repository.

However, the first stage of HDR’s move to new quarters was scheduled to begin in mid-March. Chaddic said that his target date for 1964-1966 was still the end of 1996. He noted that John Pereira of CIA had been very positive in his response to HDR and he (Chaddic) expected the HDR-CIA relationship to be very fruitful. Chaddic added that he was very well aware of the HO compilers’ problems.

In response to previously expressed concerns about the WAE payroll problem, Chaddic told the Advisory Committee that the Department of State did not intend to end the systematic review process. The question was whether current employees could replace retired annuitants. He said that HDR could use current employees if they were able to work for at least six months, but noted that there would not be total replacement. He would have to keep 1/4-1/3 of his staff.

Officers assigned to HDR should be able to speak for the bureaus (and not just refer documents), which would save declassification time. He told Kurtz that HDR had not yet received NARA’s request for a subvention.
Kimball pointed out that Chaddic would be here in the afternoon but that Page Miller would not and she had issues to raise.

Miller said that she had sent the Committee some material relating to documents on the Berlin crisis which were open in the PRO but not here. Noting that there were 78 Berlin documents not open at the National Archives, she said that she had received from Bill Burr of the National Security Archive specific documents on the Berlin crisis open in other national archives but not in the United States. Some of these had been opened as early as 1982. Charles Sampson commented that 78 documents out of thousands was not that significant. He pointed out that only four of these had been completely denied; the rest had excisions.

Slany responded that HO tried to include recently declassified documents if possible, and pointed out that such problems were much less likely to occur now that FRUS volumes were prepared in a year as compared with the old days when years elapsed. Nelson said that she also saw this as an illustration of our FGI problem, i.e., we are very restrictive and other governments seem to worry less. The meeting was then adjourned for lunch.

div.head: Luncheon Meeting, February 17, 1994
div.p: Anthony C. E. Quainton, Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security, and Patrick F. Kennedy, Assistant Secretary for Administration, joined the Committee for its working luncheon on February 17, at 12 noon.

The initial conversation was informal and involved briefing the secretaries on general aspects of declassification in the government, including pre-1950 documents still held under classification restrictions.

Professor Kimball moved the discussion to more immediate concerns of the Committee, namely the current status of the Department action plan. He stated that it was an expectation of the Committee that agencies would be informed and warned by the Department that records were about to be declassified, and that if the other agencies did not respond by sending reviewers to inspect the documents for clearance problems, then the Department should move forward, assume that the other agencies had given a silent approbation, and declassify the records in question. This approach, said Professor Kimball, has not been undertaken, and he pointed out that Joe Chaddic and Frank Machak seem unwilling to implement it.

The Committee, in general, suggested to the secretaries that it would be useful if desk officers could be briefed on the Foreign Relations statute, the deadlines it establishes for declassification, and on the spirit of openness that President Clinton has initiated. Mr. Quainton replied that, from his experience, desk officers seem to be fully aware of the President’s desires, but he suggested that the Committee might want to send a letter to the Secretary of State to request a briefing program for desk officers.

Professor Kimball brought up the matter of PRD 29 and the draft executive order, mentioning a recent letter from Bennett Freeman and some points that he made in reply. Professor Kimball wanted to stress to Messrs. Quainton and Kennedy that although the Committee supports the idea of automatic declassification at the 30-year mark and a 20-year systematic review timetable, the Committee firmly believes that the State Department approach to declassification, established by the action plan, has not set an acceptable standard that should be used as the foundation for a re-drafting of a new executive order. He pointed out that there may be some very worthy elements in the State system that are worth emulating, but there should not be a blanket transfer of the State system into the core elements of the new executive order on classification and declassification.

Mr. Quainton expressed the view that the outcome of the recent meeting on December 15 with principals from Public Affairs, Administration, and Diplomatic Security, along with members of the Advisory Committee, was general
agreement that the FRUS approach could serve as a useful model for the new draft executive order and that this approach would lead to the release of substantial quantities of documents. He reported that the Under Secretary for Management had taken this up with the NSC, and had discussed the possibility of incorporating elements of the FRUS approach into a new draft of the executive order.

Mr. Kennedy asserted that the Department would like to work with the Advisory Committee and the NSC to establish an executive order with deadlines and with some form of independent oversight. Because of limited resources, he said, we want to use a system that will deliver maximum results. The Committee agreed, and also pointed out that automatic declassification is cost effective for limited resources.

Professor Kimball returned to some of the specifics concerning the process of declassification, and emphasized that risk assessment should be used as a procedure to facilitate declassification. It could also be used to advantage in the new executive order, he said, just as it was also a feature of the Department action plan (although it has not been implemented by the Department).

Professor Kimball stated that until risk assessment is implemented by the Department, the Committee could not endorse any draft executive order containing an element of risk assessment. Mr. Kennedy assured the Committee that the Department is not against risk assessment. He stated that it would be very worthwhile for risk assessment to be written into the new executive order, because then it would make sure that it would be enforced. Mr. Kennedy
said that it would also be helpful if the Committee could scrutinize some other agencies beside the Department and offer their critique of other agency responses to declassification and to PRD 29.

Mr. Kennedy said that the Department was actively engaged in working to get a new draft executive order from the NSC. The Committee, upon hearing this, asked Mr. Kennedy if it would be possible for the Committee to see this new draft as soon as the Department receives it. Mr. Kennedy said he would make sure of it, although he pointed out that the Department might reject itself any draft coming back from the NSC that did not measure up.

Mr. Quainton said that the executive order situation is made even more complicated by the work of the Joint Security Committee, appointed by Secretary of Defense and the DCI, which is supposed to issue its report by the end of February. He said that it appeared this report would recommend a two-tier system of classification: secret (with declassification after 10 years) and secret restricted access (with declassification after 25 years).

Mr. Kennedy said that the NSC would have to meld the Joint Committee draft and any earlier or revised drafts NSC itself is producing. Mr. Quainton suggested that it might be useful for the Committee to get a briefing directly from the Joint Committee.

In conclusion, the Committee reiterated its position on a new executive order, and stressed that it should include: 1) firm deadlines for both reviews and performance; 2) independent oversight committee; 3) concept of risk assessment together with concept of bulk declassification.
Professor Kimball underscored that for any approach to work, training must be provided to those who will be implementing the program. This training, he said, was absolutely essential.
The luncheon was concluded at approximately 1:40 P.M.

div.head: Closed Session, February 17, 1994, 2:00 -2:45 P.M.
div.p: Kimball announced that Pereira of CIA would meet with the Committee at 11:00 a.m. on Friday, and the agenda would be adjusted accordingly.
Further comments were invited from Chaddic and others by Kimball.

For the record, Rosenberg wanted to express pleasure at Chaddic’s report regarding the 64-66 record bloc. She felt that the committee should go on record in full support for Chaddic’s center and the need for the Department to give high priority to its need for space and manpower.

Van Camp noted her concern about the confusion regarding HDR’s and NARA’s roles in declassification of the 64-66 bloc that had been revealed in meetings of Wednesday and this morning, had been resolved.
Kimball asked Chaddic to explain the question of risk assessment as a preliminary step to bulk opening of the records and how this related to CIA.

Chaddic gave Kimball a letter from Pereira on this. He stated that the problem related to a particular abbreviation. Pereira says the abbreviation is not classified per se; it depends on the context. Only CIA can determine whether or not it is classified in a particular context. Approximately 3 documents out of every 100 which are withheld, perhaps 2-1/2 could be released if a CIA reviewer could come and make those determinations.
Kimball asked about CIA documents in older files, noting that the working agreement had called for opening older files by a certain date if CIA did not review it.
Chaddic replied that too much pressure was counterproductive. He thinks he can get CIA to come and review withheld documents but not to make someone available full-time.
Kimball commented that this would produce a savings in processing costs; documents which CIA releases don’t have to be wrapped and tabbed.

Chaddic stated that what they were doing was neither bulk declassification nor line-by-line review but document-by-document review. Many documents can be declassified on the basis of their subject matter.
Kimball asked for the Sub-committee report by Herring and Leffler on Declassification Problems.

Herring reported on the 1961-1963 British Guiana compilation, which was previously withheld in full. It has now been partially released but has been “completely gutted.” The subcommittee agreed the compilation should not be published in this condition; it would be a “gross distortion.” He observed that it was a fascinating case study, “incredibly revealing,” despite the small size of the country involved.

Leffler agreed completely with Herring’s comments. He added that their 45 minute meeting with the desk officer proved unproductive. Leffler was concerned that the desk officer seemed to have no sense of obligation to disseminate the public record.

He suggested that the Committee appeal to the Secretary to remind Foreign Service Officers (FSOs) of their responsibility of integrity for the series. Chaddic pointed out that the law also required FSOs to protect national security. Leffler thought the FRUS law imposed some obligations on desk officers but agreed that there might be conflicting priorities.
Kimball asked if there was any objection to the subcommittee recommendation that HO take the next step in the formal appeal process.

Pryor noted that this was a tough case. The value of the material is evident, but the potential ill effects of its release are also easy to see. Lee Peters, Deputy Director of the Office of Caribbean Affairs, told her informally he would take another look at the files if the subcommittee provides him with comments. He acknowledged that publication with the present excisions would be an incomplete record. She suspected it would be very difficult to close the gap between the Committee and the desk.

Kimball asked the subcommittee if they thought further talks would do any good. Pryor saw two areas in which gaps might not be closed: 1) assessment of probable damage to US foreign relations--the task of desk officers; and, 2) the issue of what would be acceptable level of damage.
Herring felt that the Committee should push forward, if ready to treat this as a test case.

Slany noted that the law required HO to try to offer an alternative stating that we could go to the Under Secretary with a compromise. Herring responded that HO could, but Lee Peters would not buy it.

Leffler stated that the removal of details about the operation would be acceptable to the subcommittee, but they objected to removal of documents acknowledging consideration of certain activities. Herring thought it would be acceptable if material was included showing the operation was considered and agreed upon, but he did not think the desk would accept this.

Herschler noted that many of the documents were now at CIA, 14 documents had to be sent to the UK, and many required NSC review. There was general agreement that this didn’t change the legal responsibilities.

Slany requested the committee’s advice on what fell into the “operational sphere.” Kimball thought that operational versus policy was a good distinction, but Herschler answered that it was often hard to make those distinctions in reality.

George Herring stated that he was prepared to try to make those distinctions. Nelson echoed him that such was the Committee’s job. Kimball believed that the further negotiations would be worth the trouble.

The meeting moved forward with the Herring/Leffler subcommittee report on the Tibet documents in the 1958-1960 China volume. LaFantasie explained that CIA had this appeal/new submission for over nine months. The problem is with CIA’s review. CIA has released very little material, but John Pereira says they are willing to take another look, he thinks they can release more.

Herschler noted that CIA had publically acknowledged a CIA presence in Tibet, but CIA had denied virtually all the details of particular policies toward Tibet. LaFantasie observed that we don’t have CIA’s justification because there are no markings on the documents and no justifications for its excisions. Herschler also noted that CIA’s response was unofficial.

LaFantasie reported that he had spoken with Pereira about the review and expressed his unhappiness. Pereira told him that CIA was itself compiling additional documents on Tibet and reviewing them. Pereira stated that if given three months (and the expected new resources were in place), the CIA could come up with a very different result.
Herschler stated that Pereira’s colleague had indicated that there is still great resistance in the Agency to releasing material on this episode.
Betty Glad suggested that minimally CIA should give reasons for its denials and excisions.

Kimball noted that Tibet would be the first appeal to an outside agency and wondered if the Department of State would support it. Various committee members commented that the CIA might be considering its own publication program on Tibet and suggested this was a bad precedent for FRUS. Anna Nelson reminded the Committee that CIA publication were sometimes vague on provenance.

George Chalou stated that he wondered about the significance of the three month wait and asked if the appointment of a new Deputy Director might somehow change the equation? Lafantasie believed that it might, certainly CIA was holding out that possibility as a portent for improvement.

Herring complained that CIA was involved in a “snow job,” noting that he and Gaddis Smith were members of the CIA’s advisory committee which met very infrequently. He was worried about the gap between reality and rhetoric.
Kimball asked for the subcommittee’s recommendation on the Tibet documents. They recommended appeal.

Emily Rosenberg suggested that the Committee needed to talk about CIA’s publishing program. While the Committee was delighted with Woolsey’s statement, it was concerned that CIA material be incorporated into FRUS, the official method for publication of U.S. foreign policy. She suggested that this statement should be in their report. Nelson agreed that all CIA material should be available to FRUS. She also stated that the Committee didn’t want to discourage CIA from publishing documents but that FRUS should take priority. Kimball seconded this notion that FRUS is the official record and must take priority.

Glad then initiated a discussion of CIA’s special publications which she thought could be useful and certainly provided more detail than FRUS was able to. Kimball seriously questioned the value of the publications, citing the Cuban missile crisis volume as one which he thought too nitty gritty. Leffler thought that the volumes on NIE’s on the Soviet Union were useful and did not believe CIA should be discouraged from publishing.

Kimball countered the problem was that CIA special projects, especially the JFK assassination project, became excuses for not reviewing FRUS submissions. LaFantasie pointed out that the Tibet package was only 14 documents. Herschler reminded the Committee that most of HO submissions to CIA are small packages of documents.
It was agreed by the Committee that CIA must be asked to look at the Tibet documents once again.

LaFantasie then suggested that as Tibet was part of a crucial volume on U.S.-China relations 1958-1960, he recommended separating Tibet from China and placing it as a separate compilation at the end of the volume. If CIA released additional material, HO could add it without incurring too much expense and allowing the technical editors to begin work on China. If there was no action by the time the Tibet compilation was to be technically edited, LaFantasie proposed providing a notice to readers that documents were still under appeal and alerting them that if cleared they would be printed as an addendum to the 1961-1963 compilation on China.

Herring suggested that this decision should be accompanied by a press release. Nelson remarked that CIA gave wonderful speeches, yet released very little. Kimball suggested that Tibet should proceed to the next step.
The committee turned to the Picker subcommittee for its report.

Jane Picker gave a long report on her meeting with officials in the Legal Advisers Office about the publications it produces, The Digest of International Law and the Treaty Series. Picker meet with editor of the Digest Mary Ann Nash, Assistant Legal Adviser Jamie Selby, and Robert Dalton who was responsible for the Treaty Series. The conversations were awkward and difficult and Picker felt that the Legal Office officials were under the impression that she was meddling in their affairs.

Marian Nash told Picker the day before that she had completed two volumes of the Digest for 1981-1988. The first was in final pages, but the resources for the production of the second volume were somewhat murky. She had also completed and the Legal Advisers Office had published a cumulative index for the Digest for 1973-1979, but it was out of print. There was a supplemental volume of the Digest for 89-90, but there are no plans for publishing beyond 1990.

Deputy Legal Adviser Selby told Picker that afternoon that Nash’s contract would be terminated. It was not clear whether resources would be forthcoming for Part 2 of the Digest. Dalton was also present at the meeting with Selby, but the question of continued publication of the U.S. Treaties series never came up. Picker found “unexpected hostility” a surprising change from “diplomats engaging in empty pleasantries.”

Mr. Claussen suggested that L feared outside interference in internal administration. Picker replied that, as a representative of the American Society of International Law, she would report on her findings at the Society’s annual meeting. Apparently Selby thought the Digest would be terminated, but Dalton was not certain. Neither could say how widely the Digest was used. Dalton said it was mainly used by practicing lawyers; Selby said it was mainly used within L. LEXUS found 200 citations in court cases.

Picker suggested that the resources problem might be solved by outside assistance from private donations such as law professors on sabbatical. It was not so much a
matter of resources as use. “Resources” meant time spent collecting and editing, not just funds. Picker thought it was really a question of control.

State doesn’t want to publish the Digest nor does it want anyone else to. State no longer seemed to get the cooperation of other agencies. The Digest was of value to legal researchers and it would be missed. Picker also noted that she did not get a chance to discuss the fate of the Treaty Series.

Picker also got differing responses about the availability of existing volumes; if they were in storage awaiting disposal or recycling. She wondered if they could be made available to law libraries free of charge.

Picker mentioned that their files were not centralized; everyone had his or her own. Apparently the 1991 Inspector General’s report recommended discontinuing the Treaty Series. There was no coordination between L and the FRUS series. By way of background, the Department had published five digests of international law since 1908.

Since the question of treaty publication had not come up, Glad asked about secret annexes. Picker said these were subject to the same declassification process as other State Department records. Kimball suggested that HO should verify that L/T’s records are indeed in the Central Files. Dr. Slany said that Dalton had not responded to HO’s oral requests for access.

Picker lastly brought up the matter of E-mail. She assumed that hard copies were always made. Selby assumed that State abided by the law. Dalton said that he always made hard copies, but could not speak for his colleagues. All in all, her meetings with L had been disappointing. They were not even interested in seeking help from the academic community.

Mr. Leffler asked what would be in L/T’s secret files. Dr. Slany said that original texts would be; Ms. Schwar concurred. Mr. Patterson said that L had denied having secret annexes, and had asked HO about them.
Kimball said that the Committee had a sense of the problem and found L’s treatment of Picker “insulting.” He asked Picker for a short, punchy, paragraph or page on this issue.
The committee recessed for a coffee break at 3:30 p.m.

div.head: Closed Session, February 17, 1994, 3:45 P.M.
div.p: Ms. Van Camp reported on adaptation of modern technology to preservation and eventual publication of the historical foreign affairs record. She, accompanied by Humphrey, met with Rossman of the Records Management Branch on February 16 to discuss the future of record keeping. She said that the meeting served to remind her that the Advisory Committee’s responsibilities include more than declassification and Foreign Relations.
Her report focused on three concerns: (1) record-keeping practices; (2) adequacy of documentation; and, (3) Records scheduling (what is saved).

Van Camp stated that current policies and guidelines for record keeping must be revised in order to keep pace with the modern means of communication. By 1973 the traditional practice of maintaining the Central Foreign Policy File in paper files was replaced by the storage of information in electronic data bases. At that time the State Department began to track information by computer, using an on-line citation index to search for documents stored on either magnetic tape or microfiche. She mentioned the microfiche index to magnetic tape and asked how long these will last, how to declassify them? Van Camp expressed some concern regarding the preservation of, and access to, this information. The Department is involved in an effort to put cable traffic on line back to 1973.

Anna Nelson asked how documents could be declassified without paper records. Van Camp replied that the declassification issue would certainly be more complicated. Van Camp also explained that the Department was developing a “supercomputer” that would bring all cable traffic on-line, allowing for text searches.

Van Camp raised the adequacy of documentation issue, citing the potential for information being lost to an electronic filing system. She said that background material assembled in the preparation of an official document might not be preserved.
Leffler asked if anyone had reviewed the magnetic tapes to confirm the loss of such information. Van Camp replied that it was hard enough to track decisions under the old paper system.
Van Camp complained that it was difficult to get any attention within the Department on this issues. She suggested that a committee member write an appropriate article for the State magazine.

Van Camp moved to the question of how records are scheduled for retirement. She said that the records managers would require consultation from the historical community in order to avoid any unnecessary conflict. Kimball asked whether there was a problem with the disposition of records, and, if so, what the Committee could do to help. Rossman wondered whether the Department should preserve desk officers’ files. Nelson responded that, at least, the lot files are in better shape now than they used to be. Kimball stated that if Rossman had any questions he should bring them to the Committee. Slany then asked whether the Historian’s Office should conduct a periodic review of the issue.

George Chalou described a National Archives’ initiative to have historians and records managers work together, especially concerning adequacy of documentation. He felt that such efforts are necessary as a means to compare any gaps in the official record with the agency’s records schedule.

Leffler asked if Rossman saw any problems with the existing system. He suggested that Rossman draft a memo outlining these problems which would allow the Committee to offer some appropriate recommendations. Leffler voiced his great concern if historical evidence might be lost due to the mismanagement of records scheduling. Rossman replied that, while it was not necessarily happening, the potential exists that important documentation could be inadvertently destroyed.

Rossman explained that some people within the Department think that only the official record needs to be preserved, an attitude which clearly contradicts the Federal Records Act. Rossman indicated the probability that telegrams would not be around by the turn of the century. It could be all E-mail in less than 10 years, there will be no central paper files in the Department -- it will not exist.

Leffler asked Rossman if he knew whether the draft of a speech, for example, would be on magnetic tape. Nelson added that the real problem lay with the kind of documentation usually found within the lot files. Rossman replied that in less than ten years the central files would no longer exist in paper for research. The Department is currently developing a new computer system which would allow the user to search the entire database by text.
Rossman then told how the development of this computer had been delayed: a $150,000 piece of the system had been damaged when it was dropped in transit.

Humphrey asked Rossman if the new system would allow for automatic records disposition. Kimball also inquired into the status of the post files. Rossman answered that the lot files were moving toward automation, but that the post files would continue to be retired.

Jane Picker asked about diplomatic notes. Rossman replied that they were reproduced on microfilm. David Langbart also pointed out that diplomatic notes were considered official documents, and should be fully represented in the central files.

Ms. Van Camp asked that problems be brought to the attention of the committee and she asked for the help of a historian on her subcommittee. She asked to consult with Mr. Langbart and Mr. Rossman before the next meeting.

Betty Glad suggested that the Committee coordinate its efforts on this issue with working committees from their constituent professional organizations. She then asked Rossman if it was possible to delete a document electronically, to which the latter replied yes.

Kimball wondered whether the OAH or AHA were doing anything to address the future of documentation. Rosenberg and Nelson answered that there was some, but not much, interest in the matter. Kimball thought that the Committee members could check with their respective organizations. Rosenberg observed that there was some confusion: which Committee member represents which professional organization? A lively discussion of the confusion ensued.

George Herring observed that research was moving away from diplomatic history; SHAFR would be most interested. Rosenberg recalled that SHAFR once had a subcommittee; Kimball announced its premature death. Nelson said that in ten years historians would need training in subject searching. Van Camp pointed out that progress was being made. She mentioned that Rossman had been doing a good job; Nelson added Langbart’s name to the honor roll.

Van Camp cited the recent legal case concerning the Bush White House electronic records. She wondered if historians would actually use E-mail. Kimball wondered if Committee members would actually read their E-mail.

Kimball asked if Van Camp had anything else to report. Before she could reply, Langbart reminded the Committee that most electronic records are found in databases, and are therefore unlike the records most diplomatic historians are used to.

Van Camp reported on a Yale University proposal to digitize the entire Foreign Relations series. According to a friend involved in document imaging, if the proposal were approved, Yale would establish a Center for the Study of the United Nations and International Relations. As part of the project Yale would convert to digital form not only Foreign Relations but also their relevant library and manuscript collections. The system, which would be stored on CD-ROM, would include text-searching and a complete cumulative index. Van Camp explained that the proposal would be part of the Open Book project. She also thought that Yale would need to coordinate their work with HO in order to determine the possible impact of the project on the future of Foreign Relations.

Kimball wondered if HO was studying how to adapt to electronic record keeping. He then posed the rhetorical question: “Where are the Luddites when we need them?” Kimball asked Van Camp if Yale had a target date in mind. Van Camp did not think so, but thought that the project could be completed within several years. Slany acknowledged the potential impact of the project on Foreign Relations, explaining that, in contrast to the current book format, documents would be scanned in image form, including marginalia. Jane Picker wryly offered to loan someone from her over-staffed subcommittee.
Nelson asked Rossman if there would soon be more information managers than records managers. Information managers, she said, were only interested in today.

Rossman reported on several recent developments in the disposition of the Department’s records. He said that some classified INR records had been moved to the National Archives. Rossman also recently completed a study concerning the files in the Office of the Legal Adviser; a number of lot files have finally been retired, and a photo collection was transferred to Archives II.

Rossman then mentioned that he had received a call from an archivist at the Organization of American States, who complained that OAS records were completely disorganized. Kimball wondered how the Committee could help. Slany suggested the possible use of funds from NHPRC. Kimball asked Slany to look into the matter.

David Humphrey reported on the effort at the LBJ Library to process nearly 6,000 presidential phone conversations, most of which had never been transcribed from the original recordings. The dictabelt had been donated to the Library with instructions that they remain closed for 50 years.

Dr. Middleton tried to open the recordings in 1993, but the Kennedy assassination documents project took precedence. His staff will be on that project until April 15, 1994.The majority of recordings were on dictabelt, a system which was now antiquated, thereby raising preservation concerns. They want to transfer the material from dictabelts to tapes. Humphrey explained that in general
the project was proceeding chronologically, but that the LBJ Library had agreed to assign priority to 375 conversations between Johnson and his foreign policy advisers, Dean Rusk, Robert McNamara, and McGeorge Bundy.

This decision was inspired in part by McNamara’s interest in his own conversations for his own prospective memoirs. Humphrey said that the LBJ Library was concerned about the accuracy of the existing transcripts, which did not always match the dictabelt recordings. There are about 400 that have not been transcribed and the tapes should be listened to carefully before publication. The Library also did not know what to expect from the collection; revelations from the recordings, however, had already exceeded their expectations.
Rossman interjected that in 1976 he had helped transfer the recordings from Marvin Watson’s California house, a house which subsequently collapsed in the last earthquake.

Humphrey raised an important concern: the LBJ Library schedule is not necessarily in line with the Foreign Relations schedule. The Library, which has already released the material from 1963, was generally reviewing the dictabelts on a chronological basis. In other words, HO historians might have to wait for access to material, particularly from the second half of the Johnson administration.

Humphrey also cited the working conditions on the project, the people involved were tired and had been diverted from their normal duties; consequently their work would probably suffer once the JFK project was finished.

He explained that the Department already had a funded position, Charlene Burgess, who is working on the tapes. The Library has proposed that the State Department fund a second person to assist in processing the dictabelts, a two-year project for $60,000. Someone at the NARA has shown an interest in the possible position.

Glad asked if the foreign policy breakfast meetings had been captured on tape. Humphrey said that they had not. Glad then stated her conviction that foreign policy related material should take precedence. Humphrey replied that foreign policy discussions are in fact an important part of the collection. Most of the recordings cover the early years of the Johnson administration (1963-1964), and half of these concern foreign policy. Humphrey also thought that transcripts of the recordings were the best way to capture the Johnson style in a Foreign Relations volume, since he did not write anything.

Kimball asked if the LBJ Library would release the transcripts on an incremental basis. Humphrey said that he was uncertain, but that it probably would. Slany added that he had been told that the Library was inclined to do so.

Herring inquired whether declassification of these materials was likely to be more or less difficult. Slany replied that the archivists would have to create a document where one previously did not exist. Did the Committee think that the Department should spend money to assist in this effort? Nelson said that it was a matter of logistics, balancing the Foreign Relations schedule against the transcription schedule.

Would these conversations be used to help in the selection of documents or would they be considered documents in their own right? LaFantasie answered that the transcripts could be used in both ways, and that they would help fill an important gap in the record of the Johnson administration. Glad noted that Larry Berman had already shown that the timing of Johnson’s decision to escalate the Vietnam War was not reflected in the paper records, an indication that the transcription of the phone conversations could be very important.

Kimball concluded that there seemed to be a general understanding about what needed to be done. He suggested that David Humphrey draft a paragraph for the Committee justifying the funding of an additional position at the LBJ Library. The Committee could then include this language in a letter to the Secretary of State.

Picker asked if anyone knew why some tapes had been transcribed while others had not. Humphrey replied that no one was sure; in fact, some meaty conversations had not been transcribed. At least, he said, the dictabelts had held up remarkably well.
The meeting adjourned after Kimball gave some brief remarks about the agenda for the following day.

head.hi: Subcommittee Report on Declassification of Department Records

div.p: Using the list of Department of State records provided by Ken Rossman at the November meeting for the committee to use as a tool in developing advice on declassification prioritization, Anna Nelson asked whether the whole committee should comment or just she and Emily Rosenberg. Drawing from her own notes, Nelson mentioned that some lot files (e.g., economic files for 1948-1949) might be quickly reviewed and made available for researchers. She and Rosenberg had placed asterisks next to some files on the list that seemed to be critical for historical research.

Rosenberg said she preferred to defer discussion of the subject until Mel Leffler arrived, and she added that it was not a major agenda item. Warren Kimball commented that the committee was resorting the agenda and was trying to complete some business. He suggested that perhaps the committee could make its suggestions directly to Bill Slany who would sort out “disconnects” over priorities and pass on the prioritized list to Joe Chaddic.

Nelson wondered why the committee could not give their lists directly to Chaddic. The committee members would not just agree or disagree but forward some ideas on what should be the important files to be reviewed. Van Camp saw value in coordinating the Committee’s prioritization of records declassification with priorities of FRUS publication. Kimball affirmed the importance of
prioritization, as some records would have no reader demand. Chaddic said he would welcome the committee’s suggestions, believing that emphasis did not need to be placed on prioritization according to FRUS because his staff could review more than one collection at a time.

Rosenberg remarked that because the Rossman list was not detailed, it was difficult to tell what was in some of the collections. She would like to investigate further and would like Chaddic to coordinate the suggestions. Langbart noted that the Rossman list included all pre-1964 State records, not all of which had been transferred to NARA or appraised.
Kimball concluded that the committee members should give their suggestions to Slany who would pass them on the Chaddic. This took care of an afternoon agenda item.
Ken McDonald remarked that only John Pereira, not Gloria Boyd nor David Grease (who was in Miami), would be attending the meeting later in the morning.

head.hi: Report by Steve Kane on Guatemala Records

div.p: Slany then called on Steve Kane to give a report on the CIA’s progress on assembling accessible records pertaining to Guatemala. Kane explained that Slany had asked him to report on CIA documentation on Guatemala because some years ago he did the compilations on Guatemala for the 1951, and 1952-1954 Foreign Relations volumes. In looking at the material the CIA had let him sample on Guatemala, he admitted some of it had already been made available to him under the tenure (in the late 1970s) of Jack Pfeiffer as Chief Historian of the CIA. Pfeiffer had tried hard to get these documents declassified, although he was ultimately unsuccessful.

During his recent visit to the CIA, he was told there were about 60 linear feet on Guatemala covering the years 1950-1956. Kane asked CIA historian Gerry Haines to select about a dozen or so feet as representative. Kane said he never saw the manifests, but he looked at agency central cable files, DCI files, files of White House division of operations office and the office of political coordination, psychological strategy documents, and monthly operational parts, especially for 1953-1954.

Kane said he found what he expected. In other words, he uncovered no “bombshells” or “smoking guns.” His research both confirmed what historians had speculated earlier and corrected some of their errors (e.g., the size of the budget and number of armed forces). Documentation on the conduct of the operation was substantial and full. High-ranking officials in the United Fruit Company matched with the code number names.

It also revealed some internal information on the role of the State Department, although there was high CIA interest in this operation long before such interest surfaced in State. FOIA requests, in particular by (Stephen) Schlesinger and (Stephen) Kinzer, provided a solid basis for the large documentation on this operation. Ken McDonald said that the CIA has plans to declassify this material.

In reference to a question asked earlier by Slany as to whether it would be useful to create a supplementary Foreign Relations volume, Kane said this was a hard question to answer because he saw only a small part of the total documentation, and so much of it seemed to be on the operational side. This material is not in the published
Foreign Relations volume. If the CIA indeed declassified all this material, then the need for a supplementary volume would be moot.

Anna Nelson asked if these records could be declassified and released like that on the Cuban missile crisis, i.e., not transferred to the Archives but published. McDonald said his office had no present plans to prepare a supplementary or facsimile edition of the documents on Guatemala.

Betty Glad asked where the records came from. McDonald said he would discuss this later. He noted that the job numbers went back to the compiling dates of the late 1970s (Pfeiffer was fired in 1979), and this was a long time frame. Kane said the Historian’s Office fought the battle on declassification for ten years. In 1975 he thought there might be a window of opportunity, but if so, it closed.
Nelson considered 60 linear feet to be a lot of records for historical research and said that a finding aid would be necessary.

McDonald agreed that there was a lot of material but noted that Nick Cullather, a Leffler student, did the initial search for the files and wrote a classified monograph on the operation. Explanatory material, such as identification of cryptonyms, would help HO historians.

Kane assured Nelson that the collection was very well organized and easily used. Also, the study MacDonald spoke of was quite helpful if not as deep as he would have
hoped. Also, in his research, he came across several references to personal diaries which he believes may be able to fill in many gaps in the record currently put forth by this collection. For example, during his first look into this matter in the 1970’s as well as now, he finds much “backchannel” documentation missing.
Kimball stated that the Committee feels it has turned up this information (presumably alluding to HO’s recent foray into the INR files).

McDonald reminded that everything the State Department will see in these records will not be able to be declassified, and that this might have an effect on whether a supplement is a reasonable expectation.
Van Camp asked whether there was an inventory of these records and for clarification on the CIA’s current plans for declassification.

McDonald answered that his Historical Staff as well as Pereira’s declassification staff were working on three projects: Iran, Guatemala and the Bay of Pigs. He said he hoped to get the advice of an outside historian to help focus the effort so that gaps are addressed and no “surprises” impede the projects.
Herring asked when these projects could be expected to be completed.
McDonald suggested Pereira be asked that question, but guessed that Guatemala and Iran should be underway next month.

Leffler asked how we knew that this documentation represents everything on this subject. Or have we just asked for what is appropriate? McDonald replied that the documents on the Guatemala episode are well organized because they were earlier assembled for FOIA and a court order (CIA won this case). Nick Cullather also requested more from the directorates. He can’t say everything is available because of compartmentalization at the Agency and some aspects were perhaps never included in the record, but he thought we had almost everything. The files of the early 1950s are not good because the CIA was then expanding rapidly and record keeping was not always keeping up.

Leffler asked if the Guatemala collection will be less complete for these reasons than the Iran and Bay of Pigs projects. McDonald answered that the Iran project would be “so-so” and the Bay of Pigs would be better than that.

Leffler recalled that in the minutes of the last committee meeting it was mentioned that CIA records are good only during McCone’s tenure as DCI. McDonald said that was misleading. What was meant was that among DCIs only McCone kept detailed records of his meetings, memoranda, etc.

Nelson asked Kane about the central cable files. Kane replied that there were two types of cables. The first was marked “central cable files;” the second “Director’s cable files.” He is not sure now what these labels mean; we need to go deeper into it. McDonald said that about 1971 the CIA got rid of central cables after six months; this may not have occurred earlier, however.

Rosenberg wondered whether Kane was sure he had seen everything in the State Department files. Perhaps we should look for this material in State records. Kimball said it would probably be in INR, but Ted Keefer said that was not true. The INR records in State do not go back that far, but he did not know where the State records on this subject might be. Kane said that he had interviewed State Department officials, including Bill Krieg, who was stationed in Guatemala, and who made references to backchannel decisions, but he could not find the documents that might confirm these interviews.

Jim Miller suggested that the Committee might be attacking this issue from the “wrong angle.” He felt that there were enormous gaps in the documentary record and the finding aids were inadequate. There was also inadequate documentation of the contacts between posts abroad and the desks. This is an ongoing problem, and not limited just to the 1950s. McDonald added that the processing records used in FOI releases were useful in tracing much of the documentation, and that these requests did lead to fairly accurate studies by Schlesinger and Kinzer.

Nelson asked what offices administratively preceded INR. Langbart replied that previously there had been two offices. INR was raised to bureau status in 1957, but the documentation is spotty until the 1960s and 1970s.

Kimball thanked Kane for his report and called on Harriet Schwar to report on Iran. Schwar began a brief report on Iran by saying that in addition to the handful of documents that had already been reported to the committee, she had heard yesterday from a CIA historian
that he had collected about one-and-a-half linear feet of material. She had not yet looked at these documents, although they had come mostly from the Directorate of Operations and seemed to be relevant. McDonald added that he thought this material came from six or so places in the Agency.

Leffler asked how these records turned up. Kimball told Leffler that the committee had pursued the Iranian case, which had in fact been a major factor in its creation. He added that the committee had had great difficulty in obtaining any additional material on Iran. McDonald agreed that the CIA had had a problem in locating this material, which was very closely held then, in part because it involved cooperation with the British. British permission would be needed to declassify these records.

McDonald noted that British declassification after thirty years totally excludes the British intelligence service. Nothing is released about it, but Kimball wondered whether something had leaked out. Leffler remarked that one British historian (Gaserowski) had gone into this operation in depth.

In conclusion, Schwar said that the newly assembled CIA documents might be potentially important, but she could not make a judgment now. Kimball suggested that the committee defer further discussion on the issue.

Slany said that the Historian’s Office would continue to coordinate research on Iran. Kimball agreed. Glad said that full documentation was required; partial documentation and interviews would not be sufficient. Kimball added that access to the INR files was also important.

Rosenberg asked McDonald what is the timetable for completion of the 11 covert action projects, and the order in which they would be processed. McDonald said that the CIA will first concentrate on Indonesia, Tibet and the 1954 Italian elections, the so-called “big three.” Glad asked if Eastern Europe in the 1950’s is on the list of 11 covert projects approved by Woolsey. McDonald said “no,” it was not but that such a topic would be worth pursuing. He said that he and John Pereira’s people have identified the records, but do not have a target date. He said it was unrealistic to have a date for declassification.

Van Camp asked whether McDonald knew of any international effort to release information regarding Iran. McDonald said “yes,” he thought the British were gradually showing signs of becoming more open about releasing information; for instance, they have publicly acknowledged the existence of the Secret Intelligence Service. McDonald also said that if the Labor Party takes over parliament, we could probably expect even more openness, e.g., U.S.-U.K. material on the OSS.

Picker asked if McDonald had any plans to publish more material. McDonald cited several upcoming conferences at which CIA documents will be made public: Truman Conference, 1945-53, 400 pgs., KH4 Corona Reconnaissance Satellite, 1962 (or 1960-65?), 450 pgs, and next fall, a publication of Soviet Estimates, 1950-54.

Glad asked what takes priority, Foreign Relations of the United States, or the CIA covert ops studies. McDonald said, most of these documents needed to be reviewed for declassification by the CIA anyway. In
addition, his volumes would be compilations of copies of the documents themselves, rather than printed volumes, and would therefore take much less time without the editing, printing, etc. than the CIA special projects or the FRUS series. McDonald said the CIA’s Historical Review Group works on declassifying FRUS documents. His office just publishes the documents, they are not annotated like the ones in the FRUS.

Kimball said he was very concerned about the clearance of FRUS documents, specifically how the CIA’s special projects would impact the rate at which FRUS documents would become declassified. He said that in the past when the Advisory Committee had raised the issue of CIA declassifying FRUS documents, the problem that the CIA raised was one of a lack of resources, yet at the same time the CIA seemingly had the resources to spend time working on special projects. McDonald replied that he was sure that Pereira would say that these 50 to 100 pages will not get in the way, but in actuality, doing State Department work does not get priority over doing CIA work. Kimball expressed amazement that CIA priorities can come over legislation. McDonald responded that CIA’s main job is to produce CIA documents. To choose one duty over the other would hurt both parties, and therefore they are doing both CIA work and State Department work.

Glad said that they were not saying that CIA should drop their own work, but rather that they should coordinate, make an effort to work on both types of material. McDonald said that the bottom line is that they are not getting in the way of FRUS. But for the Committee to say that CIA should not do their own studies is a problem.

Kimball remarked that it is of course an issue of resources. The law (22 USC 4351 et seq.) says that the FRUS series must be on a 30 year schedule, and the agencies have 120 days to review documents for declassification. If it is a problem of resources, he questioned whether the CIA studies should take priority.

Nelson asked how much time it would take to publish these historical studies as opposed to declassifying the documents and sending them to the Archives. McDonald said that unless a study is being done, they do not declassify collections of documents. Therefore, they would not send the documents to the Archives.
Herring asked if these are new documents for the Truman period. McDonald answered that there are 60-70 new documents, and 30-35% have been declassified before.

Nelson and McDonald realized that they had misunderstood each other when they had been talking about Archives. Nelson asked if by publishing their studies, CIA was hurting FRUS more than they would by sending documents to Archives. McDonald replied no, if they didn’t have the studies, FRUS would have other problems with the documents going to Archives.
Herring asked the status of the JFK project. McDonald said that it was almost done.
Smith asked how much of the Pfeiffer collection on Bay of Pigs would be reviewed for release. McDonald replied that if CIA does Bay of Pigs, then others, there could be a problem.

Kimball brought up again the issue that taking the Director’s priorities over legislation is against the law. McDonald responded that the CIA is supposed to be in an era of openness. There are statutes dealing both with the Foreign Relations series, and the JFK documents. The JFK project is almost done, and after it is there won’t be a problem unless there are other statutory requirements.

Kimball repeated that in the meantime, they are in violation of the law and this is causing the whole FRUS series to be behind. McDonald said they they were only behind on four or five volumes. Kimball replied that this number is misleading. McDonald said that the Strategic Estimates would be out in the Fall. Gates has said that all estimates on the Soviet Union will be out soon, but this is proceeding slowly, and that this is another problem for them.

Herschler brought up declassification numbers to discuss with McDonald, but Kimball interrupted saying that we want Pereira and McDonald together for that. He asked if McDonald could stay for when Pereira was here (11:00). McDonald said that he would.
The subject turned to attribution of CIA documents.

LaFantasie said that he knows that it is an issue for Pereira, but he needed to bring up the subject of provenance. Basically, CIA does not like to publish a source note, but the series calls for one. He stated that he was specifically talking about Job Numbers. We used these in the past as an attribution source. These numbers aren’t really a source, because when documents are at Archives they aren’t grouped by Job Number, however, it is all we have.

LaFantasie continued that we’ve been told that several volumes have been held up in Wright’s office (Director, Information and Privacy at CIA) because Job Numbers are causing them to be held until they decide what to do about them. LaFantasie had promised to suspend using Job Numbers while CIA worked out the issue of provenance with the National Archives in his May 12, 1993 letter to Pereira. He said that as far as he could tell, nothing has been worked out yet. Instead, we get response letters from Wright’s office saying thank you for agreeing not to publish Job Numbers.
LaFantasie proposed to the committee that Job and Box Numbers be released and that PA/HO be allowed to create a working group consisting of PA/HO, CIA, and National Archives to work out this issue.

Nelson said that this sounded like a good solution to her. Langbart interjected that the National Archives can’t tell CIA that they have to let them use Job Numbers, but it would be great to have a method of attribution. He added that Archives cannot determine what this method would be.

LaFantasie replied that if the National Archives could give CIA some ideas of what would be a workable type of provenance, it would be helpful. Langbart responded that they have done that, but CIA doesn’t seem to be paying any attention to their suggestions.
Van Camp seconded LaFantasie’s recommendation.

Chalou spoke up, saying that a Job Number is not a provenance, it is a book keeping device. It has been used on OSS records, to pull them together. Basically, a Job Number at CIA equals a Lot Number at the State Department.

Herschler asked for clarification of what exactly a Job Number is. McDonald replied that it is a “collection of records as transferred from working records to Archives.” It is CIA’s only way to find collections of records, but then the numbers are changed, so that in the end the numbers are of no use. Leffler asked if Job Numbers are assigned by office. In other words, is one office’s records given it’s own job number? McDonald said that it tends to happen that way, but by definition, no. The shelf list shows what the contents are in a Job Number, but generally the offices do a big dump of their records much like at the State Department.

Glad asked why Job Numbers are sensitive. McDonald replied that if a Job Number on a subject gets out, the number of FOIA requests on that subject could become overbearing. Kimball chided that this wasn’t exactly holding to the spirit of the law. McDonald replied that disclosing Job Numbers would also disclose the workings of the inner offices and their names and that is against the law.
