Leffler pointed out that names of CIA offices are publicly identified in the CIA’s recently published volumes, their administrative histories. McDonald said that these histories were reviewed a while ago, and names of those offices are not sensitive anymore. Leffler said
that what McDonald said is that names of offices are out, but they will not let names of offices out, this does not make sense. McDonald said that CIA has the right to withhold names, etc. or to let them out.

Leffler asked who at CIA is responsible for provenance. McDonald replied that it is not Pereira or himself. Personally, he does not care about letting Job Numbers out. It is the Directorate for Administration that cares. Leffler again asked who specifically has responsibility. Kimball also asked so that the Committee could address a letter. McDonald said that he does not believe that it needs to be handled that formally. He agrees with LaFantasie’s idea to have a working group on this subject made up of CIA, State and NARA. He added for our information that John P. Dahms is the new Associate Deputy Director of Administrative/Information Service.

Kimball said that speaking on behalf of the committee, he endorsed LaFantasie’s two-pronged plan: 1) to resume citing provenance and, 2) to convene the above mentioned working group to resolve the provenance problem. Kimball said that if this approach failed the committee would consider taking the problem to the next level of authority. McDonald said that he thought that this informal working group would be able to solve the provenance problem. McDonald warned that if the informal committee failed to obtain the DCI’s approval, the CIA could potentially “dig in its heels”; he said the CIA if presented with an ultimatum of being forced to accept a provenance solution without its consent would very likely cite its right to withhold information, i.e. bibliographic, and this he said would be a sure way “to get no where.”

LaFantasie emphatically said that his two-pronged approach was not presented as an ultimatum, but rather as an airing of a serious concern on his part as the General Editor to maintain the integrity of the FRUS volumes.
Kimball concluded that he thought the Committee was in agreement.
The Committee recessed for a coffee break.

div.head: Closed Session, Friday, February 18, 1994, 11:00 A.M.
div.p: At 11:07 a.m., John Pereira, Director of the Historical Review Group, Central Intelligence Agency, joined the meeting.

Kimball briefly summarized the Committee’s sense and concern that there is a serious backlog at CIA of Foreign Relations material. It has now had an impact on the publications schedule and will have a greater impact in the future. Slany declined to present the problem in more detail; it was OK to address the broad issues.

Pereira pointed out that there is no one Foreign Relations “guru” at CIA; each facet of the review is handled by different directorates. He referred to the (date) letter from CIA Executive Secretary Leo Hazlewood, the intention of which was to inform the State Department that CIA was aware of the law and was committed to processing Foreign Relations material but had other demands on its resources. Hazlewood was the Executive Director of the CIA, and no one else in the Agency had as broad a mandate to address this issue as he.

Pereira recognized that the letter was not adequate, but it reflected an earlier stage. He noted that the Historical Review Group had been established and the number of reviewers had increased from 6 or 7 (with 1 for Foreign Relations) to 20 in 1992 and to 37 by the fall of 1993. This augmentation had been driven by the mandate to review the JFK assassination records and not Foreign Relations, but now that the JFK project was drawing to a close, more reviewers are being assigned to Foreign Relations. Within the last few weeks, a reviewer is assigned to each volume as it comes into the office. He used as an example the 1965 Vietnam volume: the review was finished in 8 days, and then documents were referred to the appropriate directorates.

The directorates have small review groups, and he was trying to get the four directors to focus on the Foreign Relations project. He hoped to get responses in a few weeks on review of Foreign Relations documents and access for State Department historians to CIA records. If the directors agree, it should make a difference in CIA’s responsiveness to the Department of State.

Kimball referred to the overdue volumes and said that the Committee wanted a “concrete assurance” that the backlog will receive a high enough priority to be eliminated. The Committee would like a firm commitment from the Agency.

Pereira responded that the Historical Review Group can improve the pace -- 8 volumes are in the group, 5 received in the last 4 months. The others are in the directorates. Hazlewood is the person to ask to assign
resources in the directorates. Jack Wright’s office, which is the administrative side of the process, is committed to getting Foreign Relations material logged-in in one week. That staff also has log-out responsibilities. The HRG has also, in the interest of short-cutting the process, given David Herschler unofficial copies of completed Foreign Relations reviews at the same time as they went to Jack Wright.
Kimball asked what can the Committee do. It has legal responsibilities to monitor the process and needs a firm commitment from the CIA to meet target dates.

Pereira said it was very difficult to provide dates and schedules. He said that the Agency knows that State has target dates under law, but usually such a law has an evaluation process. Kimball pointed out that we are already behind in the target dates, and Congress has been lenient and reasonable. McDonald said Congress could raise the bridge or lower the water, i.e., change deadlines or increase resources. Herschler suggested changing the process in CIA. Pereira pointed out that that was not likely, especially in the directorates, which would have to ask for more money or drop other responsibi1ities.
Nelson asked if Hazlewood was involved in the consultations with the directorates. Pereira said he is new in the job but is involved and is the decision-maker in this process.

Nelson asked if the directorates trusted the Historical Review Group to release documents. Pereira explained the process: the HRG judges what to send to the directorates, if the Group disagrees with the directorates’ decisions, then there is discussion and negotiation between them. The HRG can appeal within 30 days to the Director of the Center for the Study of Intelligence any review decision. Covert operations is an issue that must be referred to the directorates.

Kimball asked if the CIA advisory committee could look at the clearance process and make recommendations to move the pace along at a rate that is acceptable. We would like to resolve this at Pereira’s level, but we need a commitment with firm dates.

Nelson said she understood that the HRG cannot release covert actions and that the material must go the involved directorate. Pereira pointed out that the HRG makes initial decisions about declassification; their reviewers have new guidelines. The problem was in trying to change the mindset of others in the Agency.
Glad asked about the new guidelines: do they require automatic excision of the word “CIA” and others like it.

Pereira said that it depends on the document; one case where excision is still required is mention of where a station is (except in a few instances). Information from an agent can be released but the fact that a station exists can still be protected. More judgment is involved and it takes more time.

Kimball noted that the Committee can only “nibble at the edges” of the CIA process. He asked what the committee can do to solve this problem in an expeditious way. Pereira said to wait for 3-4 weeks for this new initiative to have an effect.

Herring asked what effect this new initiative will have. Pereira said there will be a speed-up in the process and a higher priority placed on Foreign Relations. Kimball asked Pereira if the priority would change in his office. Pereira pointed out that it had already changed.

Nelson and Glad asked about Wright’s office. Pereira said again that Wright’s office takes care of all the FOIA requests and the bookkeeping part of the Foreign Relations reviews. The Department and the Historical Review Group are trying to short-circuit the process at both ends. Herschler agreed, he has been delivering copies directly to HRG at the same time as officially to Wright.
Glad asked who determined priorities in Wright’s office. Pereira said that Wright’s goal is to get all Foreign Relations packages to HRG within 1 week.

Taylor asked if the speed-up in the process would mean more material was denied. Pereira answered that the HRG is trying to release more and that the directorates have to argue for any material they want to withhold. McDonald pointed out that one way to speed up the process is to deny everything. The HRG is trying to change the focus of the whole agency toward openness.
Herring asked if the process was slow because there are no people or because of these new negotiations between the HRG and the directorates. Pereira said both.

Leffler pointed out that in this transition from process to substance, the result is slow but in the long run will be better. In the case of the 1958-1960 documents on Tibet, which were returned with no additional releases, he noted the inconsistency between the current public posture of the CIA and its actual practice. Herring agreed that he was “shocked” at the result after he had been led to be more optimistic at the last meeting.

Pereira said he would also have been shocked. Tibet has been raised to a higher priority, but the Agency had always assumed that the State Department was interested in a top-down approach and would request documents that reflected policy instead of operational details. The directorates were surprised that the State Department wanted to release documents with specific operational details.

Nelson pointed out that it would be embarrassing if the Foreign Relations volumes leave documents out and then the CIA subsequently releases them. Kimball said it’s an issue of credibility. The Committee understood that McDonald and Pereira were doing all they could but they were the only two people in the Agency willing to come to meet with the Committee. But the Committee wants reviews done quickly. Several members of the Committee disagreed, saying that it was more important to get good reviews. Kimball acknowledged it was important to get reviews done expeditiously under new declassification guidelines -- get it done right and well.

Pereira said that the letter went to the right person, Hazlewood; it set up the problem in the Agency and now CIA is seized of the problem and State should give them a reasonable amount of time to solve it, a minimum of 1 month. Kimball was concerned that the Committee’s silence would lead Hazlewood to believe that the problem is solved. Pereira said no, he didn’t think so.

Leffler brought up Tibet again. CIA is publicly committed to opening up the case but is denying publication of these documents in the Foreign Relations series. How can the Committee help to break this impasse on Tibet?

Pereira said the answer is to give us time; this review was returned because of PA/HO deadlines, but the Agency is committed to review and release these documents. This case is part of the initiative to the Deputy Director regarding covert operations. McDonald pointed out that Iran and Guatemala would have to be set aside to review Tibet.

Leffler suggested focusing on the specific 10-14 documents as a microcosm of the whole case; he asked if the Committee should write a letter to the Agency. Pereira said he assumed PA/HO would appeal this decision. Herring asked if the documents were still under review. Pereira confirmed that the documents were returned only because of PA/HO’s deadlines. They are still under review because the Historical Review Group is interested in reviewing and releasing the whole case as one of the 11 covert operations.

Pereira said that PA/HO should identify what is important to have in the volumes; it was State’s responsibility to educate the CIA reviewers about the standards for the volumes. He needs this to give to others in the Agency to explain which documents are needed for the Foreign Relations volumes and why. LaFantasie pointed that HO had given the Agency copious material for the Tibet appeal. Pereira once again explained that he needed to educate the officers in the Agency reviewing Foreign Relations about the series in general. He wanted a short overview, not long detailed document-by-document analyses.

Leffler asked if the Committee could meet with reviewers to talk and reach an understanding. McDonald said it might be useful but he wasn’t sure how much it would accomplish. Leffler realized that the prevailing view in the Agency is that the academic community wanted to release material that would embarrass the Agency or reveal dirty tricks. He thought that a meeting might prove that that’s not the case.

McDonald pointed out that if there were a discussion like that of this morning, you would find yourself faced with real adversaries. Technical issues like agents in the field would impede real discussion of substance. The only place in CIA where you will get a hearing is in the Historical Review Group and the History Staff, but not among senior reviewers or the directorates. The directors can’t believe what’s happening anyway, so Leo Hazlewood was the right person to contact. The CIA is changing with the end of the cold war but very slowly.

Picker suggested participation from the CIA General Counsel in dealing with legal constraints. McDonald said that he has used the Counsel’s office to convince CIA that the October 1991 statute applies to the CIA. Kimball asked if the Committee should establish contact with the General Counsel.

McDonald replied that there is a ruling that the statute applies but the General Counsel can’t enforce it. The only “pressure point” is John Pereira -- he is the one working with this issue day-to-day. Pereira said that he can’t get the directors to read the law so he needs a working tool -- a handout -- to spell out the goals and objectives of the Foreign Relations series.

Leffler asked if Hazlewood was aware of the specific problem of Tibet. Pereira said he was not yet aware of it. Leffler asked if the Committee should send an informal letter to Hazlewood since a formal appeal will take a while. Kimball said the Committee would discuss actions in the executive session in the afternoon.

Nelson pointed out that during declassification review at Suitland all documents containing the acronym CAS were pulled from the boxes. Does CIA have an informal agreement with NARA about declassification of that particular acronym.

Van Camp said that State is making a yeoman’s effort to release 30-year old records. Of the 3% withheld, 80% have CIA equity. It would be very helpful if the CIA could assign someone to work with DOS employees to review those documents.
Pereira agreed and said he was ready to do that now. He has had an exchange of correspondence with Joe Chaddic about this.

Leffler asked about the CIA provenance problem. LaFantasie said he had talked to Pereira before this session, and Pereira suggested that the three of them (Pereira, LaFantasie, McDonald) talk together and come up with a solution, possibly with NARA input.

Pereira returned to the issue of CAS, and said that the argument in the Agency is that if the substance is released, how much is lost by deleting CAS. Nelson pointed out that at Suitland the whole document is withdrawn. Pereira said the Agency was trying to avoid denying documents in full. Russell (NARA) said it was very time-consuming to pull documents, and it would be a big help if a CIA reviewer were there.
Kimball asked if CIA would give State reviewers authority to release a certain acronym. Pereira replied that that was not acceptable now.
The Committee recessed for lunch.

head.hi: Comments from the Historical Office Staff

div.p:
Kimball called the meeting to order at 1:40 p.m. The first agenda item was input from the HO staff. Miller expressed concern that INR plans to review the documents copied by HO historians prior to making them available for use in compiling FRUS volumes. Schwar stated that it was her understanding that the review was simply to assure that the documents selected by HO historians were relevant to their research. Although HO has not actually received
any documents yet from INR, she thought the situation would work out. Keefer agreed with Schwar’s position. He went on to point out that the INR files, while very good, primarily contain detailed covert operational records. Do we want to print these? Schwar and Miller both responded that, in their view, the INR files included policy papers that lent themselves to printing. Smith pointed out that policy and operational detail were routinely mixed together in such documents. Glad asked whether summaries might substitute for such documents. Schwar responded that it would not be advisable to start with summaries, while Keefer emphasized that HO was in the business of printing documents. Keefer noted, however, that it was likely to be tough sledding getting the INR documents cleared.

Keefer raised the issue of the records of the 303 Group, the Special Committee, and the question of whether the series would want to include records with such a great level of detail. Smith indicated that Cuba provided a case study on the Oversight Committee. In covering Operation Mongoose, the series will publish a good deal of material from the Oversight Committee. It was not possible to sort out policy and operational detail at this level. There was some general discussion of this question, and it was agreed that the use of these papers would vary depending on the particular subject. Keefer pointed out that the operations covered by the Special Committee were for the most part operations no one had heard about. Slany said that it would therefore be worth leaving a summary for the records.

Gerakas asked, in light of Picker’s subcommittee report the previous day, about the use of the Legal Adviser’s Office files. This comment prompted Kimball to remind the committee that Picker was looking for an additional member or members for her subcommittee and that Van Camp was also interested in expanding the membership of her subcommittee. Picker indicated that the she would be meeting next Friday with Robert Dalton, Assistant Legal Adviser for Treaty Affairs, to discuss this question further.

Patterson indicated that he had learned this week for the first time that the Department’s Central Files for 1964-66 were undergoing declassification review. Patterson emphasized that HO historians needed to know which files were under review, which were still at Prince George’s Plaza, which were slated for the National Archives, and were any files removed from PGP and where they are located.

Pryor stated that declassified files were housed temporarily in Kenneth Rossman’s office and the still classified material from those files in Chaddic’s office. A conference room is planned for HO historians to review documents when HDR moves to the second floor.

Langbart noted that starting in September files that had been reviewed would be transferred to Archives II. Keefer indicated that this might cause a problem for HO researchers. Kimball pointed out that HO had identified a problem here that could be worked out.

head.hi: Status of the American Foreign Policy: Current Documents Series

div.p: Slany then reported on the status of the American Foreign Policy: Current Documents series. HO had resumed publication of the series in 1981 with a volume covering the Carter administration. The most recent published volume was that for the year 1990. The Office has discovered that it is stretched thin on resources. Seventy-five percent of the documents in the American Foreign Policy series were already published in Dispatch, and starting this year another part of PA will publish a CD-ROM publication with comprehensive coverage of Department speeches and statements, plus the daily press briefings, bringing the total of overlapping coverage to 85%. So HO has explored whether it might be better to eliminate Current Documents to save financially and well as resources. HO would periodically add documents to the CD-ROM publication thereby providing the usership with everything it would get from a print volume. The CD-ROM publication would go to depository libraries.

Kimball asked what sort of time frame the Office needed to receive the Committee’s advice, because the Committee should provide opinion on this question from its constituencies. In response to a question from Picker, Slany indicated that Dispatch would continue to be published. Glad said she would like to see Dispatch to see how good a job it was doing. Kimball proposed to assign action on this question to Betty Glad to determine within the next 6 weeks if a veto were necessary. Otherwise the Committee would treat this as an issue of the normal progression of new technology.

The discussion then turned to declassification problems regarding documentation proposed for publication in the Foreign Relations series on Japan. Herring, speaking for the subcommittee consisting of Leffler and himself, outlined the three issues under appeal: aspects of implementation of the Security Treaty, related military matters, and the course of Japanese politics. Herring and Leffler were agreeable to publication of the compilation without the material on two of the three issues, but that the third issue on Japanese politics posed a more serious problem. They felt that similiar problems would appear in other FRUS volumes for the 1960s, so that now was the time to take a stand on the matter.

Keefer emphasized that it was Japan at issue here and that Japan was an unusually important country. Leffler responded by noting that HO was having major problems getting material released on Tibet, an unimportant country.

Glad stated that at some point the committee may want to recommend against publishing a volume. Slany, Kimball, and Keefer discussed the appeal process and what stage HO had reached in its appeal. Leffler noted that the Historian had recommended as a solution that the volume be published without the documents that had been denied. Kimball indicated that the committee was not inclined to endorse the recommended solution. Glad asked whether the committee shouldn’t use its big gun sometime--recommending against publication. Slany and Keefer outlined the disadvantages of not publishing the compilation. For instance, the Japan desk officer would be perfectly content with such a solution. Nelson emphasized that the impact of withholding publication depends on how it is handled.

Rosenberg suggested linking together the British Guiana and Japan declassification problems. Kimball emphasized the importance of offering Assistant Secretary Moose a reasonable compromise that we can live with rather than two unpleasant alternatives. Pryor noted that State Department documents frequently do not distinguish between discussion of a policy and discussion of operational details since, at the working level, the two are usually inseparable. Thus it is difficult to find discussions of policy which are not also evidence of involvement. She noted that the FRUS legislation lays down an appeal procedure that had to be followed. Kimball stated that the Historian had already formally appealed. The next step was to go to the Secretary of State (in reality the Under Secretary of State).

A general discussion followed of alternate ways of proceeding. Kimball proposed having the subcommittee prepare sanitized documents for review by the desk officer. Kimball than ask what further recommendations the committee should make if the documents were not published as sanitized by the subcommittee. Picker warned that the committee should be careful about having a subcommittee act for the entire committee.

LaFantasie stated that he felt uncomfortable about withholding publication and that he also felt uncomfortable about our excising the documents. Slany stated that someone still had to take responsibility. Kimball indicated that he favored specific suggestions for excisions and asked the committee what it recommended. Slany suggested waiting until the next meeting for a decision. The committee agreed to do so. Leffler reasserted the importance of linking the British Guiana and Japan declassification issue.
